text.author: Marat V. Markin, Edward S. Sichel
text.title: On Expansive Mappings

p.quote:
O God , I could be bounded in a nutshell , and count myself a king of infinite space - were it not that I have bad dreams .
William Shakespeare ( Hamlet , Act 2 , Scene 2 )

text.head: 1 . Introduction
text.p: We take a close look at the nature of expansive mappings on certain metric spaces ( compact , totally bounded , and bounded ) , provide a finer classification for such mappings , and use them to characterize boundedness .

When finding an original proof to a known result describing all expansive mappings on compact metric spaces as surjective isometries ( Problem ) , we reveal that relaxing the condition of compactness to total boundedness still preserves the isometry property and nearly that of surjectivity .
We provide a counterexample of a not totally bounded metric space , on which the only expansion is the identity mapping , demonstrating that the converse to the above descriptions do not hold .

Various examples for different types of expansions are furnished , in particular the one of a nonsurjective expansion on a totally bounded “ dial set ” in the complex plane which allows us to better understand the essence of the latter .
text.head: 2 . Preliminaries
text.p:
Here , we outline certain preliminaries essential for the subsequent discourse ( for more , see , e. g. , ) .
Definition
1

p.hi: A set A in a metric space is called sequentially compact , or compact in the Bolzano-Weierstrass sense , if every sequence of its elements contains a subsequence convergent to an element of A.
A metric space is said to be sequentially compact if sequentially compact is the set X.
Remark
In a metric space setting , the above definition of compactness is equivalent to compactness in the Heine-Borel sense defined via open covers ( see , e. g. , ) .

text.p:
It is convenient for us to use a sequential definition for total boundedness as well ( see , e. g. , ) .
Definition
2

p.hi: A set A in a metric space is called totally bounded if every sequence of its elements contains a fundamental ( Cauchy ) subsequence .
A metric space is said to be totally bounded if totally bounded is the set X.
Definition
A set A in a metric space is said to be bounded if
the number being called the diameter of A.
A metric space is said to be bounded if bounded is the set X.
Remark
In a metric space , a ( sequentially ) compact set is totally bounded and a totally bounded set is bounded but not vice versa ( see , e. g. , ) .

text.head: 3 . Expansive Mappings
text.p:
Now , we introduce and further classify the focal subject of our study ,
expansive mappings
( or
expansions
) .

4

is called an expansive mapping ( or expansion ) .

text.p:
It is important for our discourse to introduce a finer classification of expansions .

Finally , an expansion such that

p.hi: Remark
Clearly , any anticontraction is necessarily a strict expansion , which in turn is also a proper expansion . However , as the following examples demonstrate , the converse statements are not true .
